ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned about the theoretical challenges and ethical dilemmas of anthropology, participant based fieldwork, anthropological approaches to studying cultures, kinship, structural violence, and the politics of representation, and notable anthropologists. The readings took us to different parts of the world, and yet made me realize an anthropological way of thinking applies to everyday life-- one of my main takeaways from this course.
Gained a different and valuable way to look at societies and cultures. Made me appreciate the discipline of anthropology.
I have gained a deeper understanding on anthropology and ethnography throughout the course, specifically globalization, racism, and culture.
I developed the ability to think critically about my surroundings, specifically the people in my surroundings and how the ways that they act and think are molded by culture

This course gave me introductory knowledge to the field of cultural anthropology. It introduced topics such as globalization, cultural relativism, and structural violence, and how these topics manifest themselves in the world around us.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The readings and lectures were interesting, allowing class discussion to be fruitful and enjoyable. Readings were challenging as they could be long and difficult, especially the theories but the ethnographies were fascinating. With less time in between classes for readings, I found it difficult to internalize ideas to form insightful and cohesive thoughts, but the discussions were well facilitated by Professor Harms so I did get a lot out of the course. The assignments were actually a great way to apply anthropological concepts and ethnographic techniques because they encouraged me to think about common rituals and behaviors in a different light than I otherwise would have.

Strengths: many free discussions, clear instructions, interactive 
Weaknesses: a bit too many readings for 5-week

the professor encourages students engagement which is awesome. only weakness is the compression of the course into 14 class meetings, which left out some material that would normally be covered during the semesters

This course was taught extremely well, and the "lectinar" format was great for the summer class. Harms is a great teacher and I learned a lot, and the pop quizzes were easy enough that I felt like I was retaining information, but in a way that wasn't super stressful. 

I do believe that the class was a lot of reading, however, although it would probably be manageable in a normal-length semester.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, this course was a great way to start learning about anthropology and cultural anthropology-- the concepts, methods, and challenges. Reading stories and having context and opportunity to talk about new concepts make it much more digestible and memorable than dense textbook learning, so I highly recommend.

Yes, I would absolutely. Anthropology is not a major option in my host college, thus it is a relatively new and interesting topic for my classmates and friends to explore. Besides, I believe that anthropology is significant to building a better society for our next generations.

Please take this course with Dr. Harms!! hes extremely inviting and understanding to students and knows how to encourage student engagement. its a great intro course whether studying anthropology or not!
YES! This course is so interesting and Professor Harms is an excellent teacher. It really makes you perceive society in ways that you wouldn't otherwise.
I would wholeheartedly recommend this course to another student. You learn information that actually pertains to life and living. It helps you to understand the world and what it has to offer.
Yes. I think the course is a great introduction to anthropology.
